content.description: From the fourth block (counting right to left) along the base, take the right leaning line past one bolt to the mid-height ledge.
content.location: center of cliff @ 4th block.

content.description:
Just right of Fissures of Men is a low roof.  Pull it and climb up and slightly left to a belay below the roof.  A fun, one move wonder.

Samael is an important archangel, a figure who is accuser, seducer, and destroyer. He has been regarded as both good and evil.
content.location: near left end of main wall.

climbs.name: Purgatory
climbs.fa: Brian Gulden, Sean Cobourn and Todd Richardson   2005

content.description: From the third block, climb the corner to the roof.  Reach left, clip the bolt and pull onto the face.  Hellish moves lead to the pine tree.
content.location: 3rd block (counting right to left) near center of cliff.

climbs.name: Opus Dei and The Knights
climbs.fa: Sean Cobourn, Todd Richardson and John Myers

content.description:
At right side of slab at right end of cliff, climb past three bolts to a belay ledge.  Second pitch is incomplete, but step right from belay to easier ground to bolt, then it will get hard.

Opus Dei = a shadowy Catholic sect = means "work of God".

Knights = Knights Templar

Band in Animal House = Otis Day and The Nights

combine them all and this is the mess you get.
content.location: right side of slab at right end of cliff.

climbs.name: No Country For Old Men
climbs.fa: Sean  Cobourn and Eddie Medina   June, 2008

content.description: Left of pitch 2 of Jacobbear, climb the left facing corner to the roof.  Pull around left under the roof to an airy perch below another roof split by twin fat cracks.  Pull this roof (crux) and climb the face above to a pair of rings.  Two ropes needed for getting down and helpful for getting up due to rope drag issues.
content.protection: Thin stuff for first half, big and small for second half.  Only fixed gear is the anchors on top.  Double ropes recommended.
content.location: Left of Black Bear Buttress is a 50 yard stroll to a smaller, scruffy looking cliff.  At the first wall before heading down to the base of it, seek a vertical wall covered with incut holds and 2 bolts.  This is the first pitch of Jacobbear.  Climb this to a spacious ledge and a nice horizontal tree to bealay from.  The nearest corner up to a small roof is pitch 2 of Jacobbear.  Left of this is an obvious left facing corner capped by a roof.  This is the route.

content.description:
We had some reporters from Raleigh tagging along that day and we feared we would be....

A needless concern as it turned out.  The "story" was only a few photos and 4 lines of print.

There are four large blocks along the base of the wall.  From the fourth one (counting right to left) take the obvious line up and left to the ledge.  Directly above looms a large roof.
content.location: 4th big block at base.  near center of cliff.

content.description: From the pine tree, climb the left wall to and out the overhanging arete until you hit a hanging belay.  Lower off into space.
content.location: at pine tree in center of cliff.

climbs.name: Merovingian Line
climbs.fa: Sean  Cobourn, Eddie Medina and Todd Richardson   2005

content.description:
At the right side of the cliff is a big steep slab.  At the left side of the slab is an obvious line.  Climb past three bolts to the crack and follow it to a run out section with two far spaced bolts then up to a bolted belay right of a pine tree.

The Merovingians were a Frankish dynasty that came to rule the region largely corresponding to ancient Gaul from the mid fifth to the mid eighth century.

Merovingians were also claimed to be the descendants of Jesus Christ; this is seen as popular pseudo-history by most academicians.
content.location: left side of slab at right side of cliff.

climbs.name: Lost Puppies
climbs.fa: Shannon Milsaps and Ed Williams    Nov. 2007

content.description: From ledge beneath Z crack roof, climb the thin finger crack to the right side of the roof.  Pull right side of roof to top.
content.location: At left end of cliff.  Climb Fissures of Men, Samael or The Last Start to ledge beneath Z crack roof.

climbs.name: The Last Start
climbs.fa: John Myers, Sean Cobourn and Todd Richardson   2005

content.description: Just right of Samael is a crack.  Climb it to the tree below the roof.  Start is harder than it looks.  This was the last of the natural starts to the midway ledge to be done.
content.location: near left end of main wall.

content.description: Climb to middle ledge.  Take the prominent line between the roofs.  Heavenly!
content.location: center of cliff.

content.description: This is the Z crack roof. At left end of cliff, climb a route to the mid height ledge.  Jam, heel hook and contort your way out and over the lip of the Z crack roof.  Belay at a tree.  Learning to climb in the Gunks has its advantages.
content.location: left end of main wall.

climbs.name: Jacobbear
climbs.fa: Eddie Medina and Sean Cobourn   June 2008

content.description:
Pitch 1: Step onto the wall, climb incut edges past two bolts.  There is a TCU placement and/or a bush to sling higher up.  Mantle onto a moss covered ledge and belay at the tree.  5.6

Pitch 2:  Climb the obvious corner nearest the tree.  Pull the roof to the right.  continue to the top of the pedestal and belay off a tree.  To descend, scramble down and north to the rings above No Country For Old Men.  Two ropes needed to get down.
content.protection: NC trad rack up to 3 Camalot.  2 bolts on first pitch.
content.location: 50 yards left of Black Bear Buttress proper is a scruffy looking cliff.  At the right side of the crag is a steep wall littered with incuts and sporting 2 bolts.

climbs.name: The Illuminati
climbs.fa: Tim Raymer, Sean Cobourn and Allan Irwin Nov. 07 for second pitch

content.description:
P1. Climb face past two bolts to a ramp.  From top of ramp cut right to belay.

P2. Climb up past two bolts (crux) to a crack.  Follow face up and left to belay shared w/ other routes.

"The Illuminated Ones" are the masterminds behind events that will lead to the establishment of a New World Order.
content.location: Near right end of cliff, just left of Opus Dei.

content.description: At left end of main cliff is a clean blocky crack.  Ascend it to a ledge of sorts below the obvious Z crack roof.  see photo
content.protection: Normal rack, some big cams or hexes
content.location: Left side of main wall.

content.description: Above the second boulder at base (counting right to left) is a lone bolt.  climb the thin layback flake to the pine tree.  Easiest way to middle ledge.
content.location: 2nd boulder near center of cliff.

climbs.name: The Devil's Rejects
climbs.fa: Sean Cobourn, Brian Gulden and Todd Richardson   2005

content.description: From the third block at the base (counting right to left) step up, traverse left a few moves to a sweet finger crack sporting a piton for some ungodly reason.  Belay at tree.
content.protection: no bolts.  one piton.  natural gear (small)
content.location: center of cliff @ third block.

content.description:
Middle of steep slab wall at right side of cliff.  Climb past two bolts to a bowl.  Climb up and left, then pull the crux bulge back right.  Head up and right to a short crack, then slab back left past two bolts to the bolted belay right of pine tree.

Name refers to the blood relatives of Jesus (he had brothers and sister ya know).
content.protection: some bolts, small gear.  double ropes highly recommended.
content.location: center of slab on right end of cliff.

content.description: Climb Fissures of Men to the ledge.  Either belay or continue up the right facing corner left of the Z crack roof, to the top.
content.protection: Normal rack, some big stuff for Fissures.
content.location: Left end of main wall.

content.description: From the pine tree climb the left wall up and right to the roof.  Pull the roof and headwall above to a hanging belay.
content.protection: natural gear.  May have a bolt, I can't remember.
content.location: pine tree in center of cliff.

climbs.name: Black Bear Flake
climbs.fa: John Myers and Sean Cobourn   2005 - FFA Ed Williams and John Myers

content.description: From the third boulder at the base, climb the obvious right facing corner to the pine tree.  Some rotten rock down low.
content.location: center of cliff below pine tree.
